Denouncement by top elections and legal: The top elections and legal officials in Michigan jointly denounced the robocall, labeling it as racist and inaccurate. Michigan Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson stated that the call was an attempt to lie to citizens about their right to vote and preyed on voters' fear and mistrust of the criminal justice system.
Confirmation of false claims: The expert's verdict confirms that the claim made in the robocall, stating that personal information provided for mail-in voting would be used by police departments and credit card companies, is false. The CDC's alleged push to use records for mail-in voting to track people for mandatory vaccines is also debunked.
Investigation and reporting of complaint: After receiving a complaint about the robocall, Michigan's Attorney General's office set up a website for individuals to report receiving the call. Approximately 20 reports have been received so far, and authorities are actively working to find the individuals behind the effort.
Identification of right: wing provocateurs: The speaker on the robocall claims to work for a civil rights organization founded by Jack Burkman and Jacob Wohl, who are known right-wing provocateurs accused of spreading misinformation. The state is currently working to confirm the identity of the individuals responsible for recording and distributing the robocall.
